26.text: And like most of you, I suspect, I don't really believe

29.text: that people can see into the future.

30.text: I don't believe in precognition, and every now and then,

33.text: you hear that somebody has been able to predict something that happened in the future,

36.text: and that's probably because it was a fluke, and we only

39.text: hear about the flukes and about the freaks.

42.text: We don't hear about all the times that people got stuff wrong.

46.text: Now we expect that to happen with silly stories

48.text: about precognition, but the problem is,

51.text: we have exactly the same problem in academia

54.text: and in medicine, and in this environment, it costs lives.

59.text: So firstly, thinking just about precognition, as it turns out,

62.text: just last year a researcher called Daryl Bem conducted

65.text: a piece of research where he found evidence

67.text: of precognitive powers in undergraduate students,

70.text: and this was published in a peer-reviewed academic journal

73.text: and most of the people who read this just said, "Okay, well,

75.text: fair enough, but I think that's a fluke, that's a freak, because I know

77.text: that if I did a study where I found no evidence

80.text: that undergraduate students had precognitive powers,

83.text: it probably wouldn't get published in a journal.

86.text: And in fact, we know that that's true, because

89.text: several different groups of research scientists tried

92.text: to replicate the findings of this precognition study,

95.text: and when they submitted it to the exact same journal,

98.text: the journal said, "No, we're not interested in publishing

101.text: replication. We're not interested in your negative data."

105.text: So this is already evidence of how, in the academic

108.text: literature, we will see a biased sample of the true picture

113.text: of all of the scientific studies that have been conducted.

117.text: But it doesn't just happen in the dry academic field of psychology.

121.text: It also happens in, for example, cancer research.

125.text: So in March, 2012, just one month ago, some researchers

129.text: reported in the journal Nature how they had tried

132.text: to replicate 53 different basic science studies looking at

140.text: and out of those 53 studies, they were only able

145.text: Forty-seven out of those 53 were unreplicable.

150.text: And they say in their discussion that this is very likely

156.text: People will do lots and lots and lots of different studies,

158.text: and the occasions when it works they will publish,

161.text: and the ones where it doesn't work they won't.

162.text: And their first recommendation of how to fix this problem,

166.text: because it is a problem, because it sends us all down blind alleys,

169.text: their first recommendation of how to fix this problem

171.text: is to make it easier to publish negative results in science,

175.text: and to change the incentives so that scientists are

177.text: encouraged to post more of their negative results in public.

182.text: But it doesn't just happen in the very dry world

186.text: of preclinical basic science cancer research.

190.text: It also happens in the very real, flesh and blood

197.text: some researchers did a study on a drug called lorcainide,

200.text: and this was an anti-arrhythmic drug,

202.text: a drug that suppresses abnormal heart rhythms,

204.text: and the idea was, after people have had a heart attack,

207.text: they're quite likely to have abnormal heart rhythms,

208.text: so if we give them a drug that suppresses abnormal heart

211.text: rhythms, this will increase the chances of them surviving.

214.text: Early on its development, they did a very small trial,

219.text: Fifty patients got lorcainide, and of those patients, 10 died.

223.text: Another 50 patients got a dummy placebo sugar pill

226.text: with no active ingredient, and only one of them died.

229.text: So they rightly regarded this drug as a failure,

231.text: and its commercial development was stopped, and because

234.text: its commercial development was stopped, this trial was never published.

238.text: Unfortunately, over the course of the next five, 10 years,

244.text: other companies had the same idea about drugs that would

248.text: prevent arrhythmias in people who have had heart attacks.

250.text: These drugs were brought to market. They were prescribed

252.text: very widely because heart attacks are a very common thing,

255.text: and it took so long for us to find out that these drugs

259.text: also caused an increased rate of death

262.text: that before we detected that safety signal,

265.text: over 100,000 people died unnecessarily in America

271.text: from the prescription of anti-arrhythmic drugs.

278.text: the researchers who did that 1980 study, that early study,

281.text: published a mea culpa, an apology to the scientific community,

285.text: in which they said, "When we carried out our study in 1980,

288.text: we thought that the increased death rate that occurred

290.text: in the lorcainide group was an effect of chance."

294.text: The development of lorcainide was abandoned for commercial reasons,

296.text: and this study was never published;

297.text: it's now a good example of publication bias.

300.text: That's the technical term for the phenomenon where

302.text: unflattering data gets lost, gets unpublished, is left

306.text: missing in action, and they say the results described here

309.text: "might have provided an early warning of trouble ahead."

314.text: Now these are stories from basic science.

317.text: These are stories from 20, 30 years ago.

322.text: The academic publishing environment is very different now.

325.text: There are academic journals like "Trials," the open access journal,

329.text: which will publish any trial conducted in humans

332.text: regardless of whether it has a positive or a negative result.

335.text: But this problem of negative results that go missing in action

339.text: is still very prevalent. In fact it's so prevalent

343.text: that it cuts to the core of evidence-based medicine.

349.text: So this is a drug called reboxetine, and this is a drug

352.text: that I myself have prescribed. It's an antidepressant.

354.text: And I'm a very nerdy doctor, so I read all of the studies

357.text: that I could on this drug. I read the one study that was published

360.text: that showed that reboxetine was better than placebo,

363.text: and I read the other three studies that were published

365.text: that showed that reboxetine was just as good as any other antidepressant,

368.text: and because this patient hadn't done well on those other antidepressants,

370.text: I thought, well, reboxetine is just as good. It's one to try.

373.text: But it turned out that I was misled. In fact,

376.text: seven trials were conducted comparing reboxetine

379.text: against a dummy placebo sugar pill. One of them

381.text: was positive and that was published, but six of them

384.text: were negative and they were left unpublished.

388.text: Three trials were published comparing reboxetine

389.text: against other antidepressants in which reboxetine

392.text: was just as good, and they were published,

393.text: but three times as many patients' worth of data was collected

398.text: which showed that reboxetine was worse than

400.text: those other treatments, and those trials were not published.

408.text: Now you might say, well, that's an extremely unusual example,

410.text: and I wouldn't want to be guilty of the same kind of

415.text: that I'm accusing other people of.

417.text: But it turns out that this phenomenon of publication bias

419.text: has actually been very, very well studied.

421.text: So here is one example of how you approach it.

423.text: The classic model is, you get a bunch of studies where

426.text: you know that they've been conducted and completed,

428.text: and then you go and see if they've been published anywhere

430.text: in the academic literature. So this took all of the trials

433.text: that had ever been conducted on antidepressants

435.text: that were approved over a 15-year period by the FDA.

439.text: They took all of the trials which were submitted to the FDA as part of the approval package.

443.text: So that's not all of the trials that were ever conducted on these drugs,

446.text: because we can never know if we have those,

448.text: but it is the ones that were conducted in order to get the marketing authorization.

451.text: And then they went to see if these trials had been published

454.text: in the peer-reviewed academic literature. And this is what they found.

456.text: It was pretty much a 50-50 split. Half of these trials

460.text: were positive, half of them were negative, in reality.

463.text: But when they went to look for these trials in the peer-reviewed academic literature,

468.text: what they found was a very different picture.

470.text: Only three of the negative trials were published,

474.text: but all but one of the positive trials were published.

479.text: Now if we just flick back and forth between those two,

483.text: you can see what a staggering difference there was

485.text: between reality and what doctors, patients,

489.text: commissioners of health services, and academics

492.text: were able to see in the peer-reviewed academic literature.

495.text: We were misled, and this is a systematic flaw

503.text: In fact, there have been so many studies conducted on

505.text: publication bias now, over a hundred, that they've been

509.text: collected in a systematic review, published in 2010,

512.text: that took every single study on publication bias

516.text: Publication bias affects every field of medicine.

519.text: About half of all trials, on average, go missing in action,

523.text: and we know that positive findings are around twice as likely

526.text: to be published as negative findings.

529.text: This is a cancer at the core of evidence-based medicine.

533.text: If I flipped a coin 100 times but then

537.text: withheld the results from you from half of those tosses,

540.text: I could make it look as if I had a coin that always came up heads.

544.text: But that wouldn't mean that I had a two-headed coin.

546.text: That would mean that I was a chancer

547.text: and you were an idiot for letting me get away with it. (Laughter)

550.text: But this is exactly what we blindly tolerate

554.text: in the whole of evidence-based medicine.

558.text: And to me, this is research misconduct.

562.text: If I conducted one study and I withheld

565.text: half of the data points from that one study,

568.text: you would rightly accuse me, essentially, of research fraud.

573.text: And yet, for some reason, if somebody conducts

576.text: 10 studies but only publishes the five that give the result that they want,

580.text: we don't consider that to be research misconduct.

583.text: And when that responsibility is diffused between

585.text: a whole network of researchers, academics,

589.text: industry sponsors, journal editors, for some reason

594.text: but the effect on patients is damning.

597.text: And this is happening right now, today.

602.text: This is a drug called Tamiflu. Tamiflu is a drug

605.text: which governments around the world have spent billions

608.text: and billions of dollars on stockpiling,

610.text: and we've stockpiled Tamiflu in panic,

613.text: in the belief that it will reduce the rate of complications of influenza.

617.text: Complications is a medical euphemism for pneumonia

625.text: Now when the Cochrane systematic reviewers

628.text: were trying to collect together all of the data from all

630.text: of the trials that had ever been conducted on whether Tamiflu actually did this or not,

634.text: they found that several of those trials were unpublished.

637.text: The results were unavailable to them.

639.text: And when they started obtaining the writeups of those trials through various different means,

643.text: through Freedom of Information Act requests, through

645.text: harassing various different organizations, what they found was inconsistent.

649.text: And when they tried to get a hold of the clinical study reports,

655.text: the best possible rendition of the information,

658.text: they were told they weren't allowed to have them.

661.text: And if you want to read the full correspondence

664.text: and the excuses and the explanations given by the drug company,

667.text: you can see that written up in this week's edition

674.text: And the most staggering thing of all of this, to me,

678.text: is that not only is this a problem, not only do we recognize

682.text: that this is a problem, but we've had to suffer fake fixes.

686.text: We've had people pretend that this is a problem that's been fixed.

689.text: First of all, we had trials registers, and everybody said,

691.text: oh, it's okay. We'll get everyone to register their trials, they'll post the protocol,

695.text: they'll say what they're going to do before they do it,

697.text: and then afterwards we'll be able to check and see if all the trials which

699.text: have been conducted and completed have been published.

701.text: But people didn't bother to use those registers.

703.text: And so then the International Committee of Medical Journal Editors came along,

706.text: and they said, oh, well, we will hold the line.

708.text: We won't publish any journals, we won't publish any trials,

710.text: unless they've been registered before they began.

713.text: But they didn't hold the line. In 2008, a study was conducted

716.text: which showed that half of all of trials published by journals

719.text: edited by members of the ICMJE

722.text: weren't properly registered, and a quarter of them weren't registered at all.

727.text: And then finally, the FDA Amendment Act was passed

730.text: a couple of years ago saying that everybody who conducts

732.text: a trial must post the results of that trial within one year.

736.text: And in the BMJ, in the first edition of January, 2012,

740.text: you can see a study which looks to see if people kept

742.text: to that ruling, and it turns out that only one in five

762.text: And this is not a difficult problem to fix.

766.text: We need to force people to publish all trials

771.text: conducted in humans, including the older trials,

774.text: because the FDA Amendment Act only asks that you publish the trials conducted after 2008,

778.text: and I don't know what world it is in which we're only

781.text: practicing medicine on the basis of trials that completed in the past two years.
